content:
I built an AI operating system that improves itself every session.

Intelligence score: 72 → 93 out of 100.

5 new safety systems prevent it from breaking itself.

22 skills. 8 agents. 6 access-controlled profiles.

Here's how it works:

The hardest problem in agentic AI isn't making it smart.

It's preventing smart systems from modifying their own config and making themselves dumber.

ACOS v9.3 could learn. But it couldn't validate whether what it learned was actually an improvement.

v10 adds 5 systems that solve this:

1. Experience Replay — remembers what worked
2. Agent IAM — least-privilege access control
3. Immutable Audit Trail — every action logged
4. Circuit Breaker — stops cascading failures
5. Self-Modify Gate — auto-reverts bad changes

Experience Replay: every session generates a trajectory — tools used, order, outcome.

When you start a new task, the system finds the 2 most similar past successes and injects them as context.

60+ trajectories. 67% avg success rate. Getting better.

Agent IAM scopes each of 6 profiles to exactly the tools and directories they need.

Music producer can't edit system configs. Content writer can't run bash.

Least-privilege for AI agents. Same principle as enterprise security.

Circuit Breaker tracks failures per file:
- 3 failures: warning
- 5 failures: restricted
- 8 failures: full stop

Prevents the most common AI failure mode: trying the same broken approach 8 times.

Self-Modify Gate — the most important safety system.

1. Snapshot config
2. Apply change
3. Re-score intelligence
4. Score drops >5pts? Auto-revert.

The system can evolve. It can never make itself significantly dumber.

v10 is also faster.

Hooks: 15 → 7. Subprocess spawns per tool: 5-6 → 1-2.

Removed informational-only hooks. Consolidated tracking. Less noise. More signal.

The honest version: v7 claimed 630+ skills and 158 agents.

An audit revealed 630 were unvetted npm installs. 158 were empty session timestamps.

v8-v10 rebuilt on truth. 22 real skills. 8 real agents. Every number verified.

ACOS is open-source and free.

Full breakdown of all 5 systems:
https://frankx.ai/blog/acos-v10-autonomous-intelligence

GitHub: https://github.com/frankxai/agentic-creator-os

Type /acos and describe what you want. The system handles the rest.

linkedin.content:
I shipped an AI operating system that scores 93/100 on an intelligence benchmark. Up from 72 in the previous version.

The difference isn't more features. It's 5 safety systems that let the system modify its own rules without breaking itself.

The Core Problem: Every agentic system faces the same trap — the smarter it gets, the more it can modify its own configuration. Unchecked self-modification eventually makes it worse.

5 Systems That Fix This:

1. Experience Replay — finds 2 most similar past successes, injects as context
2. Agent IAM — 6 profiles scoped to exactly the tools/directories they need
3. Immutable Audit Trail — append-only JSONL logging every action
4. Circuit Breaker — 3 failures = warning, 5 = restricted, 8 = full stop
5. Self-Modify Gate — snapshots config, re-scores after changes, auto-reverts if score drops >5 points

The Honest Part: v7 claimed 630+ skills and 158 agents. An audit revealed 630 were unvetted npm installs and 158 were empty timestamps. v8-v10 rebuilt on verified numbers.

Results: Intelligence 72→93 (+29%), Hooks 15→7 (-53%), Subprocess spawns 5-6→1-2.

Open-source: github.com/frankxai/agentic-creator-os

How are you handling self-modification safety in your agentic systems?

#ArtificialIntelligence #AIEngineering #DevTools #OpenSource

Intelligence score jumped from 72 to 93 out of 100. The key: 5 new systems that let it modify its own rules while preventing it from making itself dumber.

Experience Replay remembers what worked. Agent IAM enforces least-privilege. Immutable Audit Trail logs everything. Circuit Breaker stops cascading failures. Self-Modify Gate auto-reverts bad config changes.

22 curated skills. 8 specialist agents. 6 access-controlled profiles.

The honest version: v7 claimed 630+ skills. An audit revealed they were unvetted npm installs. v10 is built on truth.

content:
I had 18 MCP servers loading every Claude Code session. 8 were broken. 4 were duplicates. Session startup was slow and tools failed silently.

So I built a tool to fix it.

The problem nobody talks about: MCP servers accumulate silently. You install a few manually. Plugins auto-install others. Claude.ai connectors add more. Before long, your config is 1,000 lines across 4 scopes.

Three failure patterns I found after debugging all 18:

1. Scope confusion — same server in user + project scope
2. Silent failures — broken servers give a brief warning and vanish
3. No tiering — every server loads every session, even the ones you use once a month

mcp-doctor does in 10 seconds what took me 30 minutes:

- Scans all scopes (user, project, claude.ai)
- Health checks each server with real MCP handshakes
- Detects duplicates and missing env vars
- Recommends always-on vs on-demand vs remove

Results on my own setup:

18 servers → 5 always-on
8 broken → 0 broken
4 duplicates → 0 duplicates
Health score: 50/100 → 100/100

It includes 10 preset packs: web-developer, content-creator, ai-architect, data-engineer, devops, security, minimal.

Each pack tells you exactly which MCPs to keep always-on and which to add on-demand.

Free, open source, MIT licensed.

npx mcp-doctor audit

https://frankx.ai/blog/mcp-doctor-claude-code-server-optimization

linkedin.content:
I had 18 MCP servers loading every Claude Code session.
8 were broken. I didn't know.

MCP servers are the extensibility layer that makes Claude Code powerful — browser automation, memory, image generation, Slack integration. But they accumulate silently.

Plugins auto-install them. Claude.ai connectors add more. Your colleague shares a config with 5 servers you don't need. Before long, every session spawns 18 processes and half of them fail quietly.

After spending 30 minutes manually debugging my setup, I identified three patterns that trip up every Claude Code user:

1. Scope confusion — servers registered across 4 different scopes with duplicates
2. Silent failures — broken servers show a brief warning and disappear
3. No tiering — everything loads at startup whether you need it or not

So I built mcp-doctor. A TypeScript CLI that:
- Scans your entire Claude Code config across all scopes
- Health-checks each server with actual MCP handshakes
- Detects duplicates, missing env vars, scope conflicts
- Recommends always-on vs on-demand vs remove
- Generates copy-paste fix commands

Results on my own setup: 18 servers down to 5 always-on. Zero broken. Zero duplicates. Noticeably faster startup.

It also includes 10 preset packs (web-developer, ai-architect, content-creator, minimal, etc.) so you can start with a curated setup instead of guessing.

Free and open source. Run it in 10 seconds:
npx mcp-doctor audit

Full writeup on the blog with the technical details.

#ClaudeCode #MCP #DeveloperTools #AITooling #OpenSource

newsletter.subject: I built a doctor for broken MCP servers
newsletter.body:
I had 18 MCP servers loading every Claude Code session. Eight were broken. Four were duplicates. Session startup was slow and tools failed silently — and there was zero tooling to tell me what was wrong.

So I built mcp-doctor.

It scans your entire Claude Code config across all scopes, health-checks each server with real MCP handshakes, detects duplicates and missing environment variables, and gives you copy-paste fix commands. Took my setup from 18 broken servers to 5 clean always-on servers in under a minute.

It also includes 10 preset packs (web-developer, ai-architect, content-creator, etc.) so you can start with a curated setup instead of accumulating random servers over time.

Free, open source, MIT licensed: npx mcp-doctor audit

Full technical writeup here: https://frankx.ai/blog/mcp-doctor-claude-code-server-optimization

content:
Simon Willison co-created Django and coined the term "prompt injection."

His approach to AI engineering is the opposite of every hype thread you've read.

3 principles that actually work in production:

Principle 1: Treat the LLM as an observed system.

Not a black box. Not magic.

Type hints. Schema definitions. Structured constraints.

The clearer your boundaries, the less the model hallucinates. This is engineering, not vibes.

Principle 2: The exploratory coding loop.

Never ask AI to "build a whole app."

Instead:
- Small testable chunks
- Immediate execution
- Feed results back into context

High frequency. Small surface area. That's how you ship reliable code with LLMs.

Principle 3: Assume the model is untrusted.

No direct shell access. No raw database queries. Hard boundaries between AI output and system execution.

The person who named prompt injection runs his own systems this way. That should tell you something.

The pattern across all 3 principles:

Constraints make AI better, not worse.

Type hints > hope.
Small loops > big prompts.
Hard boundaries > trust.

Pragmatism scales. Magic doesn't.

Full breakdown with video timestamps and content atoms:
https://frankx.ai/blog/ai-engineering-without-hype-willison

If you're building with LLMs, this is the protocol.

linkedin.content:
Simon Willison co-created Django and coined the term "prompt injection." His approach to AI engineering is the opposite of the hype cycle.

No magic. No promises. Just three principles that hold up in production.

1. Treat the LLM as an observed system. Type hints and schema definitions reduce hallucination more than any clever prompt trick. The clearer your constraints, the more predictable the output.

2. The exploratory coding loop. Never ask AI to build a whole app. Instead: small testable chunks, immediate execution, feed results back into context. High frequency iteration beats ambitious prompting every time.

3. Assume the model is untrusted. No direct shell access. No raw database queries. Hard boundaries between AI output and system execution. This is the same principle behind enterprise security, applied to AI.

The pattern: constraints make AI better, not worse. Type hints over hope. Small loops over big prompts. Hard boundaries over trust.

I wrote up the full protocol with video timestamps and practical extraction points for content creators and engineers.

https://frankx.ai/blog/ai-engineering-without-hype-willison

How are you keeping pragmatism in your AI stack?

#AIEngineering #LLMs #SimonWillison #SoftwareArchitecture #PracticalAI

newsletter.subject: The anti-hype AI engineering protocol
newsletter.preview: Simon Willison's 3 principles for building with LLMs that actually work.
newsletter.body:
Simon Willison co-created Django and coined the term "prompt injection." His approach to AI engineering is the most pragmatic I've seen.

Three principles:

1. Treat the LLM as an observed system — type hints and schema definitions beat clever prompting.
2. Use the exploratory coding loop — small chunks, immediate execution, feed back into context.
3. Assume the model is untrusted — hard boundaries between AI output and system execution.

The through line: constraints make AI systems better, not worse. This matches what we've learned building ACOS and every production AI system I've worked on.

Full writeup with the video, timestamps, and content atoms: https://frankx.ai/blog/ai-engineering-without-hype-willison

content:
I turned Claude Code into a personal intelligence system that manages 12,000 songs, a production website, and enterprise consulting.

Not a chatbot. An operating system.

Here's the 3-layer architecture:

Layer 1: Knowledge.

One file — CLAUDE.md — in your project root.

It contains your projects, preferences, past decisions, and coding patterns.

Claude reads it at session start. Every session starts where the last one ended. No re-explaining.

Layer 2: Execution.

MCP servers connect Claude to your entire stack:
- File system for code edits
- Vercel for deployment
- Slack for notifications
- Resend for email

It doesn't just think. It does.

Layer 3: Intelligence.

Pattern recognition across sessions. The system learns which approaches work for your codebase.

After 30 days: 60+ trajectories, 67% success rate, getting better.

Your AI assistant has a memory now.

The setup takes 10 minutes:

1. Create CLAUDE.md in project root
2. Add your preferences and patterns
3. Install 3-5 MCP servers
4. Build your first skill (reusable workflow)

In 30 days you'll wonder how you worked without it.

Free, open source.

https://frankx.ai/blog/build-your-own-jarvis-claude-code

GitHub: github.com/frankxai/agentic-creator-os

linkedin.content:
I manage 12,000 AI-generated songs, a production website, and enterprise consulting projects. All through one tool: Claude Code, configured as a personal intelligence system.

Not a chatbot you prompt from scratch every session. An actual operating system that knows your work.

The architecture has three layers:

1. Knowledge Layer — a CLAUDE.md file in your project root that contains your projects, preferences, past decisions, and coding patterns. Claude reads it at every session start. No re-explaining.

2. Execution Layer — MCP servers that connect Claude to your file system, deployment pipeline, Slack, email, and databases. The AI doesn't just suggest code. It edits files, deploys to Vercel, sends notifications.

3. Intelligence Layer — Pattern recognition across sessions. The system tracks which approaches work (60+ trajectories, 67% success rate) and applies them to new tasks.

The setup takes 10 minutes. In 30 days, you'll have an AI system that knows your codebase, your preferences, and your workflow patterns.

I open-sourced the whole system. Full tutorial with step-by-step instructions.

https://frankx.ai/blog/build-your-own-jarvis-claude-code

content:
White-collar jobs are being automated faster than anyone expected.

But here's what most people miss: the same AI tools causing the disruption just made it cheaper than ever to start a business.

The transition from employee to builder is now the lowest-risk path.

The math changed.

2020: Starting a business = $50k+ upfront, team of 5, 18 months to revenue.

2026: Starting a business = $200/month in tools, team of 1 + AI agents, revenue in weeks.

The barrier to entry collapsed. The ceiling didn't.

Three things AI gave you that didn't exist 3 years ago:

1. An engineering team (Claude Code, Cursor)
2. A marketing department (content generation, SEO)
3. A design studio (Midjourney, v0, Canva)

One person can now do what took 10.

The jobs most at risk are the ones that pay well but follow patterns:
- Legal research
- Financial analysis
- Code review
- Marketing copy

The safest position isn't inside a company. It's owning the business that deploys the AI.

This isn't about quitting your job tomorrow.

It's about building an asset on the side. Right now. While you still have a salary.

The window won't stay open forever.

Full breakdown with data and a 90-day action plan:
https://frankx.ai/blog/the-great-transition-build-your-own-business

content:
After 500+ tracks on Suno, I figured out why most prompts fail.

Suno doesn't follow instructions. It captures vibes.

"Make the drums louder" won't work.
"Powerful driving drums" will.

Here's the formula that actually works:

The Suno prompt formula:

Genre + Tempo + Instruments + Vocals + Mood + Special Elements

Example: "Cinematic orchestral, 90 BPM, sweeping strings and brass, ethereal female vocals, triumphant and expansive, with a dramatic build"

That's 10x better than "epic movie music."

Genre stacking is the secret weapon.

Don't write: "rock"

Write: "Alternative rock meets post-punk, angular guitars, tight rhythm section, deadpan vocals"

The more specific you are about the intersection, the more original the output.

Vocal control tips from 500 sessions:

- "Whispered verses, belted chorus" gives dynamic range
- "Baritone" or "soprano" sets register
- "No vocals, instrumental only" when you want pure music
- "Humming intro" creates atmosphere before lyrics hit

The biggest mistake: writing a prompt once and hoping.

Suno is iterative. Generate 4 versions. Pick the best direction. Refine the prompt based on what worked. 3 rounds of this beats 1 perfect prompt every time.

Full guide with genre-specific formulas, 50+ tested prompts, and advanced techniques:
https://frankx.ai/blog/suno-prompt-engineering-complete-guide

500+ tracks. Here's everything I learned.

linkedin.content:
I've created over 500 tracks on Suno AI. Here's the single biggest insight from all that experimentation:

Suno doesn't follow instructions. It captures vibes.

"Make the drums louder" won't work. "Powerful driving drums" will. This fundamental difference trips up almost everyone.

The formula that consistently produces good results:

Genre + Tempo + Instruments + Vocals + Mood + Special Elements

Example: "Cinematic orchestral, 90 BPM, sweeping strings and brass, ethereal female vocals, triumphant and expansive, with a dramatic build"

That generates something 10x better than "epic movie music."

Three techniques that changed my output quality:

1. Genre stacking — don't write "rock." Write "Alternative rock meets post-punk, angular guitars, tight rhythm section, deadpan vocals." The intersection creates originality.

2. Vocal control — "whispered verses, belted chorus" gives dynamic range. "Baritone" or "soprano" sets register.

3. Iterative refinement — generate 4 versions, pick the best direction, refine. Three rounds beats one "perfect" prompt every time.

I published the complete guide with 50+ tested prompt formulas across genres.

https://frankx.ai/blog/suno-prompt-engineering-complete-guide

Anyone else experimenting with AI music generation?

#SunoAI #AIMusicProduction #PromptEngineering #CreativeAI #MusicProduction

newsletter.body:
After creating 500+ tracks on Suno AI, I've distilled everything into one insight: Suno doesn't follow instructions, it captures vibes.

The formula: Genre + Tempo + Instruments + Vocals + Mood + Special Elements.

Three techniques that matter most: genre stacking for originality, vocal descriptors for control, and iterative refinement over single-shot prompting.

Complete guide with 50+ tested prompts: https://frankx.ai/blog/suno-prompt-engineering-complete-guide

content:
Claude Code went from beta CLI to the dominant AI pair programmer in 12 months.

But the documentation alone won't make you good at it.

Here are the 5 resources that actually teach you how to think with Claude Code:

1. Simon Willison — The Architect.

Doesn't just demo tools. Explains how LLMs think when they read your file system.

His "LLM OS" concept is essential for understanding what Claude Code actually does under the hood.

2. Fireship — The Speedrunner.

When Anthropic drops a feature, Fireship has the fastest breakdown.

100 Seconds of Claude Code updates > 45 minutes of reading release notes.

3. The official CLAUDE.md guide.

Most people skip it. The context file is the single highest-leverage thing you can configure. It turns Claude from generic assistant to project-specific expert.

4. MCP Server ecosystem.

Claude Code's real power is tool integration. Slack, Vercel, databases, image generation — all through MCP.

Understanding MCP is the difference between chat and operating system.

Full list with direct links and learning paths:
https://frankx.ai/blog/claude-code-mastery-top-resources

But mastering it requires more than reading the docs. You need to watch the masters at work.

The 5 resources that actually define the Claude Code meta right now:

1. Simon Willison — explains how LLMs think when reading your file system. His "LLM OS" concept is foundational.

2. Fireship — fastest, most concise breakdowns of every Anthropic feature drop.

3. The official CLAUDE.md guide — the context file is the single highest-leverage configuration. Most people skip it.

4. MCP server ecosystem — tool integration turns Claude from chatbot to operating system.

5. The community patterns emerging from power users building production systems.

content:
72% of enterprise AI projects now use multi-agent architectures.

Up from 23% in 2024.

The shift from "single agent" to "agent ecosystem" happened faster than anyone predicted.

Here's the 2026 roadmap:

Three frameworks dominate:

1. LangGraph — stateful workflows, graph-based orchestration
2. CrewAI — team coordination, role-based agents
3. MCP — universal tool integration (Claude's secret weapon)

You need to understand all three.

The market: $5.4B (2024) to $7.8B (2025), projected $52B by 2030.

45.8% CAGR.

OpenAI replaced Swarm with Agents SDK. Anthropic's MCP improved accuracy from 49% to 88% on complex tasks. Oracle launched 50+ pre-built agents.

For creators and solopreneurs: multi-agent systems let you build what used to require a team.

Content pipeline: research agent + writer agent + SEO agent + distribution agent.

All coordinated. All automated. One person's business.

For enterprises: the governance question is now urgent.

Who approves agent decisions? How do you audit multi-agent workflows? What happens when agents disagree?

The companies solving this in 2026 will own the next decade.

Full roadmap with activation checklists for creators, founders, and executives:
https://frankx.ai/blog/agentic-ai-roadmap-2026

linkedin.content:
72% of enterprise AI projects now use multi-agent architectures. Up from 23% in 2024.

The AI agents market grew from $5.4B to $7.8B in one year, projected to reach $52B by 2030 at 45.8% CAGR.

Three frameworks are defining the space:

1. LangGraph for stateful workflows and graph-based orchestration
2. CrewAI for team coordination and role-based agents
3. MCP (Model Context Protocol) for universal tool integration — improved accuracy from 49% to 88% on complex tasks

For solopreneurs and creators: multi-agent systems let one person do what used to require 10. A content pipeline with research, writing, SEO, and distribution agents. All coordinated. All automated.

For enterprises: governance is now urgent. Who approves agent decisions? How do you audit multi-agent workflows? The companies solving this in 2026 will own the next decade.

I published a comprehensive roadmap with activation checklists for three audiences: creators building AI-powered businesses, founders deploying agents in products, and executives governing agent ecosystems.
